metadata.sermon_start_end: A few years ago my husband and I were spending the weekend fat a summer colony not unlike this one. The summer chapel service there was always packed. Many people attended the summer chapel who never went to church anywhere else. At a dinner party the conversation turned to this subject. [...] We come together to hear the living voice of a living Lord, who has passed through the domain of death and hell and emerged victorious, bearing the keys with him. He has the words of eternal life. May we all today put our trust in him, as we come to know that he is the Holy One of God. Amen.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon centers on the Johannine text, specifically the tension between those who leave and the confession of Peter. However, it leans heavily on general theological distinctions (religion vs. faith) rather than mining what is unique to John 6 that cannot be found elsewhere. The 'scandal of particularity' is mentioned but remains somewhat abstract.
quotes: This turning away begins at the end of the sixth chapter, after the great discourse on the Bread of Life.
The fact that one pericope always underlies the sermon compels the preacher to be specific...
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus more on the specific 'Bread of Life' imagery and the physical 'eating of flesh' which causes the offense in this specific text, rather than shifting to general Freud/Isaiah critiques.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher understands the basic narrative arc of John 6 and the offense taken by the 'religious authorities.' However, there is no evidence of Greek word study or deep historical-critical engagement with the Capernaum context. It stays on a narrative-thematic level.
quotes: This he said in the synagogue, as he taught at Capernaum.
The religious authorities take offense at him. They 'murmured at him'
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate deeper exegesis of the term 'Holy One of God' or the specific Johannine meaning of 'Eternal Life' as a present reality.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is very concrete, utilizing the TWA Flight 800 disaster and the specific setting of the 'summer colony.' It avoids vague 'be good' moralism and addresses the actual zeitgeist of secularism and the 'I don't need it' attitude.
quotes: I thought about that this week when the news came of the fiery end of TWA Flight 800.
Your rector was out on the water with the Coast Guard for two days after the TWA catastrophe.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Ensure the application flows from the text's specific 'hard saying' rather than just using the text as a springboard for a discussion on suffering.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon starts with application (the dinner party), moves to exposition, and then back to application. While not strictly separated into two blocks, the transitions are somewhat abrupt. The hearer is 'expounded' alongside the text primarily in the middle section.
quotes: Let me propose a little mental exercise. Picture yourself at a cocktail party.
Jesus thus becomes even more specific, and now he angers not only the pooh-bahs but his own disciples
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Try to let the contemporary 'cocktail party' scenario be interpreted by the 'Capernaum synagogue' scenario simultaneously throughout the sermon.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon deals heavily with 'misery' (the crash, the helplessness, the 'hard saying'). Redemption is clearly outside of man (not religion, but Christ). Gratitude is present in the final call to trust, though less emphasized.
quotes: Religious ideas … are illusions, fulfillments of the oldest, strongest, and most urgent wishes of mankind.
The eternal God... has come down... in order to deliver us from everlasting sin and death.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' aspect by showing how Peter's confession is not just a lack of alternatives, but a gift of the Spirit.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is a strong point. The sermon explicitly addresses the possibility of being 'lost'—both temporally (the crash) and eternally (rejecting the words of life). It takes the 'Do you also wish to go away?' as a serious, non-rhetorical question.
quotes: If it is the Lord Jesus Christ and his words of eternal life that she is rejecting, then that is a different matter.
He has passed through the domain of death and hell and emerged victorious.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Maintain this sharpness; perhaps clarify the 'eternal loss' without softening it as 'unfortunate' but as a 'destination'.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: The sermon is highly Christocentric. Christ is the telos. The distinction between 'religion' (man-made) and 'revelation' (Christ) is the backbone of the argument. It upholds the two natures (God come down).
quotes: The one who reveals a God whom none of us could ever have imagined.
In the cross of Jesus, the flood has gone over the head of its Creator.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'words of eternal life' to the 'flesh and blood' mentioned earlier to ground the grace in the Incarnation.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in just under 20 minutes (around 18-19 minutes). According to Dekker's strict Thesis 8, it lacks the 'breadth' required for full 'depth'.
quotes: A sermon that lasts less than 20 minutes cannot be a sermon.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical section (Thesis 2) to reach the 20-25 minute mark, providing more 'breadth' to the biblical exposition.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon is a strong theological address that successfully distinguishes between human 'religion' and divine 'revelation.' It falls short of Dekker's ideal primarily in its length (slightly under 20 minutes) and a lack of technical exegetical depth (original languages/context). However, it excels in its concrete application to the zeitgeist and its refusal to shy away from the 'two ways' and the reality of being lost.
strengths: Sharp distinction between religion as a human construct and Christ as revelation.
Concrete contemporary application using the TWA crash and the secular 'I don't need it' attitude.
Strong Christocentric focus where Christ is the sole source of salvation outside the self.
weaknesses: Insufficient length according to the 20-minute rule.
Lack of specific exegetical detail regarding the original Greek or historical Capernaum context.
The 'uniqueness' of this specific passage (John 6) is sometimes traded for general systematic theological points.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition, though it requires more 'breadth' and exegetical 'labor' to reach the required depth. It successfully avoids the 'bicycle mechanic' error by mounting the wheel of the Gospel firmly on the axle of Christ's specific revelation.
